author: wsjcom
title: What’s News: Business & Finance
text:
0 COMMENTS The House approved a bipartisan bill that makes modest changes to the Dodd-Frank law, cutting regulations for small banks and raising an asset threshold for larger lenders.
U.S. banks’ profit climbed 28% last quarter to a record $56 billion, a result of the new tax law, rising rates and an improving economy.
Amazon has banned shoppers for infractions such as too many returns, sometimes without telling them what they did wrong.
Zuckerberg apologized to EU lawmakers over Facebook’s handling of user data but avoided responding to many difficult questions.
Penney CEO Ellison is quitting his job to take over leadership of Lowe’s.
Univision named media veteran Sadusky as CEO of the Spanish-language broadcaster, succeeding Falco.
New Venezuela sanctions are expected to further crimp the country’s oil output and could boost crude prices.
Santos rejected Harbour Energy’s offer of over $10 billion for the Australian oil-and-gas firm.
The Dow fell 178.88 points to 24834.41 on concern over trade tensions and North Korea talks.
Calpers said its finance chief has left, as the public pension fund wrestles with more executive turnover.
An ex-Valeant executive was found guilty of defrauding the drug company.
